/etc stores system-wide settings for (mostly) console programs and daemons (i.e. system services)
application settings are generally in a hidden directory in a user's home
generally speaking, each program puts its settings wherever it wants, in whatever format it wants
so you can have, for example, /home/silent/.someprogram/someprogramrc ("rc" being a common suffix for "configuration file")
GNOME programs, on the other hand, use the GConf framework, which is quite similar to the Windows registry, but more lightweight
try typing "apt-cache show gconf-editor" if you want to peek at it

as he said, only for *systemwide* settings.
GUI applications that are configured by the single users have their settings saved in the user's home directory -- and those won't be "purged"
